items.title: find_dotenv() not finding .env file in cwd
items.body:
dotenv version: 0.14.0
OS: Ubuntu
Python version: 3.6

It seems that python_dotenv is always using the path of the file that contains the call to `load_dotenv()` instead of the cwd.

We have a file structure similar to this
```
repo_root
    -- lib
        -- lib
             base_class.py
        .env
        Pipfile
    -- app
        -- app
             main.py
       .env
       Pipfile
```
So we have an application in one project/folder, using the base class defined in another project/folder. The PYTHONPATH of the application includes the path to the lib project. The virtual environment of the app contains all the dependencies defined in Pipfile.

The base class of the application contains the code for loading the environment variable. When I run the app from the folder `repo_root/app`, `find_dotenv()` finds the `.env` file in `repo_root/lib` (where the call to `load_dotenv()` actually is) instead of the cwd.

items.title: Feature proposal: .env.local and .env.[environment][.local]
items.body:
Hi,

Is there a way to deal with local configurations or environment dependent configurations?. 

I will explain my idea:

 On the process of developing an app, You would have  a .env  file stored on the version control with a default options (a template with default values). But when you are on the development process you need a .env.local. Why? becouse you need to store your DB conection string and other config values related with your local environment.  Next, on your publishing/test/stage scenario your connection strings will change so you will need a different environment file:

IMO the load secuence of the .env will be the follwing:

On development scenario:

- .env // default options
- .env.development // common development options
- .env.local

On the other scenarios:
- .env
- .env.[staging/production]

Is there a way to configure this behaivour on the library ? if is not do you have plans to add this behaiour? I ask this because i can add this functionality to the library and make a PR if you consider it useful.

items.title: Override / interpolate of variables working incorrectly
items.body:
Bug is a combination of override and interpolate.

contents of files is as follows:

foo.txt
```
Name=foo
Interpolate="${Name}/baz"
```

bar.txt
```
Name=bar
Interpolate="${Name}/baz"
```

test file:
```
from dotenv import load_dotenv
import os

def print_env():
    for key in os.environ.keys():
       print("{}: {}".format(key, os.getenv(key)))

load_dotenv('foo.txt', override=True)
print_env()

load_dotenv('bar.txt', override=True)
print_env()
```

when second `print_env()` runs, the values are:
```
Name=bar
Interpolate=foo/baz # should be bar/baz
```

the reason for this is that the [resolve_nested_variables](https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv/blob/master/src/dotenv/main.py#L213) method looks into existing ENV vars first and then looks at the current file's loaded values. (in our case, `Name` was loaded in the earlier file with value `foo`). 

I believe the correct functionality would be to first look into the loaded file's values and then on the environment in order to keep the same behavior as the first file loaded.

items.title: TypeError: argument should be string, bytes or integer, not PosixPath with README.md example
items.body:
Using the example in the README.md file as is:

```python
# OR, explicitly providing path to '.env'
from pathlib import Path  # python3 only
env_path = Path('.') / '.env'
load_dotenv(dotenv_path=env_path)
```

throws the `TypeError: argument should be string, bytes or integer, not PosixPath` error. 

I believe that the correct example should be:

```python
# OR, explicitly providing path to '.env'
from pathlib import Path  # python3 only
env_path = Path('.') / '.env'
load_dotenv(dotenv_path=env_path.name)
```

items.title: path variables like tidle (~) don't get expanded
items.body:
I use a `.env` file with pipenv [1] and I'd expected to have a variable that aliases a path from the current users home directory:

```
clayg@banana:~/Workspace/scratch/mytest$ env | grep -i mydir
clayg@banana:~/Workspace/scratch/mytest$ pipenv shell
Loading .env environment variables...
Launching subshell in virtual environment...
clayg@banana:~/Workspace/scratch/mytest$  . /home/clayg/.local/share/virtualenvs/mytest-GzP8C70q/bin/activate
(mytest) clayg@banana:~/Workspace/scratch/mytest$ env | grep -i mydir
MYDIR=~/Workspace/scratch/mytest
(mytest) clayg@banana:~/Workspace/scratch/mytest$ cd $MYDIR
bash: cd: ~/Workspace/scratch/mytest: No such file or directory
(mytest) clayg@banana:~/Workspace/scratch/mytest$ source .env
(mytest) clayg@banana:~/Workspace/scratch/mytest$ cd $MYDIR
(mytest) clayg@banana:~/Workspace/scratch/mytest$ echo $?
0
(mytest) clayg@banana:~/Workspace/scratch/mytest$ cat .env 
export MYDIR=~/Workspace/scratch/mytest
```

As a workaround I've noted I can use:

```
export MYDIR=${HOME}/Workspace/scratch/mytest
```

I'm confident python's expanduser [2] could be used for cross-platform expansion but I'm not sure where to apply it since the posix variable regex won't notice ~ and call the replacement method [3].

1. https://pipenv-fork.readthedocs.io/en/latest/advanced.html#automatic-loading-of-env
2. https://docs.python.org/2/library/os.path.html#os.path.expanduser
3. https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv/blob/784102284471252f418e797c1874a00063426210/src/dotenv/main.py#L233

items.title: Feature request: Support multiple .env files based on environment?
items.body: I'm not sure if this is already an existing feature. Is there a way to have multiple .env files in a repository in which an environment variable controls which is used? This could be useful in having a different .env file for dev, staging, and production. Alternatively, being able to do this in the same .env file would be useful as well if multiple files is not possible.

items.title: dotenv run breaks out of venv on windows
items.body:
On windows, for python versions 3.7.3 and higher, activating a virtual environment created with the `venv` module and executing `dotenv run something.py` does not use the correct, `venv` provided python interpreter, but the global one instead. For me, this breaks using `dotenv run` in poetry-managed projects to replace pipenv, which handles loading variables from `.env` files natively.

This is no direct fault of python-dotenv, but seems to happen because of [python issue 38905](https://bugs.python.org/issue38905), which describes the wrong interpreter being used in `subprocess` calls. I can confirm that simply using `subprocess.Popen` shows the same issues on the affected python versions for us.

Interestingly, this only applies to virtual environments created using `venv`, those created using the `virtualenv` package seem to be fine. Still we would like to keep using poetry which relies on `venv`.

Any ideas how to mitigate this, without having to downgrade python?

The issue  goes away when I re-source my venv on the command line, or reload my window in VS Code via `Developer: Reload Window`

I suppose all's well that ends well, but curious to understand the why?

items.title: Breaking change in 0.10.5
items.body:
The release 0.10.5 breaks some invalid case parsing.

In .env:
```
LOL='mdr','xd'
```

In toto.py:
```
import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()
print(os.environ['LOL'])
```

Version 0.10.3:
```
$ poetry run python toto.py
mdr
```

Version 0.10.4
```
$ poetry run python toto.py
Python-dotenv could not parse statement starting at line 1
mdr
```

Version 0.10.5
```
$ poetry run python toto.py
Python-dotenv could not parse statement starting at line 1
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "toto.py", line 5, in <module>
    print(os.environ['LOL'])
  File "/home/…/.pyenv/versions/3.7.3/lib/python3.7/os.py", line 678, in __getitem__
    raise KeyError(key) from None
KeyError: 'LOL'
```

I know it was a bug before, or the string was not correctly parsed, and the behavior it has now is the expected one. But it worked before, even in a wrong way, and now it breaks. I know too this is a pre-release, not a stable one, as a majority of python lib, but still some people use it everyday in production.

I don't know what to propose to avoid this situation in the future. The release number could have been bumped to 0.11.0, but as I actually use the environs which does not lock the version of python-dotenv, the result would have been the same.

items.title: Warning for consecutive lines that are comments
items.body: With #211 (v0.10.4), if there are consecutive lines that are comments, there will be a warning for each line after the first. because `key` and `value` will be `None`, passing the check for the warning. The only reason the first line does not have a warning is because it is considered as part of the line before, since the regular expression for comments captures any whitespace, including newlines, at the beginning.

items.title: Add support for variables with no value
items.body:
In a quest for a `.env` lib for [docker-compose](https://github.com/docker/compose) we would like to integrate `python-dotenv` replacing the home brewed solution. 

But there is a feature missing, which is variables with no value like in [this test](https://github.com/docker/compose/blob/master/tests/fixtures/env/resolve.env) where the variables `ENV_DEF` and `NO_DEF` should be fetched from the environment (if possible).

So as return of `dotenv_values()`, that would be a key with value `None`. With this approach, the decision on what to do is up to the caller. In our case, we look for it in the current environment, fulfilled with the value found or suppressed if not present.

items.title: set_key doesn't escape values with quotes in them
items.body:
Suppose you have this code:

```python
import dotenv
import json

key = "KEY_TO_SAVE"
value = json.dumps({"test": "me"})
dotenv.set_key(".env", key, value)
```

What I would expect to see is a `.env` file that looks like this:

```
KEY_TO_SAVE="{\"test\": \"me\"}"
```

However what I actually see is this:

```
KEY_TO_SAVE="{"test": "me"}"
```

Because of the lack of escaping quote character, dotenv has effectively changed the value I was trying to set. In this case, the value passed to dotenv is valid JSON, but the value dotenv saves to the file is not valid JSON.

items.title: dotenv in Django
items.body:
Hi,

Maybe these results will help someone else. After experimenting with Django I discovered that python-dotenv worked differently depending on how the server was launched.

1. With ./manage.py runserver 0.0.0.0:8000

In this case, there were no issues.  Place the .env file in the same directory as settings.py and wsgi.py, and load it with something as simple as:

```
from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()
```

2. From apache2 (or maybe nginx also...)

The apache configuration looked something like this:

/etc/apache2/conf-available/django.conf

```
<IfModule mod_wsgi.c>
  WSGIDaemonProcess django python-home=/home/django/env python-path=/home/django/repo/
  WSGIProcessGroup django
  WSGIScriptAlias / /home/django/repo/mysite/wsgi.py
  WSGISocketPrefix /var/run/apache2/wsgi
</IfModule>
```

Interestingly, the following did _not_ work anymore:

```
from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()
```
or
```
from dotenv import load_dotenv, find_dotenv
load_dotenv(find_dotenv())
```
The solutions were:

- Hardcoded absolute path. Although that's not ideal, it was a fix:

```
from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv(dotenv_path="/home/django/repo/mysite/.env")
```

- Computed absolute path. Preferred.

settings.py and wsgi.py:

``` 
import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv
dotenv_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '.env')
load_dotenv(dotenv_path)
```

items.title: Import of typing should be conditional
items.body:
Hey -- so we vendor this library over in pipenv and I recently updated to the latest release before realizing that there is now a hard dependency on `typing`.  We don't vendor typing and I'd rather avoid that, but it's also not strictly necessary to put unguarded `typing` imports everywhere.  They are slow, for one thing, or they can be, and they break on systems where typing isn't available.

What I often do is include a utility method that sets a variable if the type checker is running, something like this (in `utils.py` or `environment.py`):

```python
def is_type_checking():
    try:
        from typing import TYPE_CHECKING
    except ImportError:
        return False
    return TYPE_CHECKING


IS_TYPE_CHECKING = os.environ.get("MYPY_RUNNING", is_type_checking())
```

If that solution makes sense here, I'm happy to PR it.  I'll open a PR and feel free to merge or close as needed

items.title: Inconsistency with os.environ and str/unicode in Python 2
items.body:
In Python 2, `os.environ` is a map with `str` keys and `str` values, not `unicode`.  Unfortunately, values loaded with Python-dotenv are `unicode`.

Example with `test.py`:

```python
import os

import dotenv

dotenv.load_dotenv()
print(type(os.environ["foo"]))
```
and `.env`:

```bash
foo=bar
```

Results:

```
> python test.py
<type 'unicode'>
> env foo=bar python test.py
<type 'str'>
```

I think that it's probably not worth fixing given Python 2's upcoming end of life, but I'm pointing this out here because this might justify turning off some Mypy type warnings for Python 2.

items.title: Breaking changes in 0.10.0 and future changes
items.body:
As reported by several users in https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv/pull/148, version 0.10.0 changed how some .env files are parsed in a breaking way, especially with regards to escapes.  I think some of those changes were necessary, but some other may have been unexpected.

## Experiment

It was unclear what exactly broke and whether Python-dotenv is consistent with other parsers, so I ran an experiment to compare versions and packages.

The scripts to generate these tables are in [bbc2/dotenv-parser-comparisons](https://github.com/bbc2/dotenv-parser-comparisons).  I may update them if I find new interesting behavior.

### Basic

```
foo=ab
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `a` `b` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` `b` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` `b` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` `b` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` `b` |

### Escaped `z`

```
foo=a\zb
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `a` `\` `\` `z` `b` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` `z` `b` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |

### Escaped and single-quoted `z`

```
foo='a\zb'
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |

### Escaped and double-quoted `z`

```
foo="a\zb"
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` `\` `z` `b` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` `z` `b` |

### Escaped `n`

```
foo=a\nb
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `a` `\` `\` `n` `b` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` `\` `n` `b` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` `n` `b` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` `\` `n` `b` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` `\` `n` `b` |

### Escaped and single-quoted `n`

```
foo='a\nb'
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `a` `\` `n` `b` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` `\n` `b` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` `\` `n` `b` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` `\` `n` `b` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` `\` `n` `b` |

### Escaped and double-quoted `n`

```
foo="a\nb"
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `a` `\` `n` `b` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` `\n` `b` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` `\` `n` `b` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` `\n` `b` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` `\n` `b` |

### Quoted newline

```
foo="a
b"
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `"` `a` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` `\n` `b` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` `\n` `b` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` `\n` `b` |

### Non-escaped space

```
foo=a b
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `a` ` ` `b` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` ` ` `b` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` ` ` `b` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` ` ` `b` |

### Non-escaped `#`

```
foo=a#b
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `a` `#` `b` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` `#` `b` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` `#` `b` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` |

### Non-escaped spaced `#`

```
foo=a #b
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `a` ` ` `#` `b` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` ` ` `#` `b` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` |

### Escaped `#`

```
foo="a#b"
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `a` `#` `b` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `a` `#` `b` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `a` `#` `b` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `a` `#` `b` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `a` `#` `b` |

### UTF-8

```
foo=é
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `\` `x` `e` `9` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `é` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `é` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `é` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `é` |

### Quoted UTF-8

```
foo="é"
```

| parser | output |
|--|--|
| python-dotenv-0.9.1 | `é` |
| python-dotenv-0.10.1 | `é` |
| bash-5.0.0 | `é` |
| js-dotenv-6.2.0 | `é` |
| ruby-dotenv-2.6.0 | `é` |

## Conclusion

1. Non-quoted escapes (valid or invalid): All up-to-date parsers except Bash do the same thing.  Bash removes the `\`.  0.9.1 added a `\`, which was obviously incorrect.
2. Single-quoted invalid escapes: Everything is fine.
3. Single-quoted valid escapes: 0.10.1 is the only parser that interprets them as control characters.
4. Double-quoted invalid escapes: It's fine except for Ruby.
5. Double-quoted valid escapes: All up-to-date parsers except Bash do the same thing.  Bash and 0.9.1 keep the original characters instead of interpreting them as control characters.
6. Pound sign `#`: Interpreted as a comment delimiter since 0.10.0 if unquoted, even if there is no whitespace preceding it.  When quoted or prefixed with whitespace, everything is fine except for JavaScript.
7. Non-quoted UTF-8: Fixed in 0.10.0.  When quoted, everything is fine.
8. Non-escaped space: Only Bash ignores everything after it (or treats the rest as a command).  Other parsers include everything until the end of the line.

My opinion:

* (2, 4, 7) are OK.
* (1, 5, 8) are where Bash differs from other parsers.  It isn't obvious what we should do.
* (3, 6) are where python-dotenv 0.10.0 is quite obviously broken and should be fixed.

items.title: dotenv run does not pass through command output
items.body:
`dotenv run` is implemented with the `run_command` function in `main.py`. It uses `subprocess.Popen` and does not pass output through to stdout and stderr.

Would it be possible to reimplement `run_command` with `os.execvpe`? I think it makes more sense to only use dotenv for loading the environment and let the OS run the process.

items.title: Parser does not support trailing comments
items.body:
For `.env`, we use the following pattern:

```bash
export KEY="value" # comment
```

Actual behavior after we parse such file:

```python
>>> os.getenv('KEY')
'"value" # comment'
```

Expected behavior:

```python
>>> os.getenv('KEY')
'value'
```

The tricky part here is that `#` can be contained within the quoted value (e.g. `KEY="#"`), so we can't ignore everything after the `#`.

What is worse, `bash` requires `#` to be at the beginning of the token, so something like this is valid:

```
bash$ KEY=#value
bash$ echo $KEY
#value
```

[Ruby dotenv][0] works fine with trailing comments, but it uses a complicated [regular expression][1] to do that.

[0]: https://github.com/bkeepers/dotenv
[1]: https://github.com/bkeepers/dotenv/blob/879af5e04fd09e450153b63bc443b1be043f2d56/lib/dotenv/parser.rb#L14-L30

items.title: Stdout/stderr output isn't flushed out by `dotenv run`
items.body:
For example, running django web server normally sends continuous output to stdout/stderr; however, via python-dotenv it doesn't show the server output. This may have something to do with the fact that python-dotenv is [using `subprocess.Popen` and then `p.communicate()`][2] (which collects all the output when the process returns).

Here's a quick reproducing script, and output:

```python
import logging
import sys
import time

logging.basicConfig()  # set default stderr handler
log = logging.getLogger()
stdout_handler = logging.StreamHandler(sys.stdout)
log.addHandler(stdout_handler)
print('Starting running with handlers', log.handlers)

while True:
    log.error('Test log')
    time.sleep(1)
```

and the output:

```bash
$ python test.py
Starting running with handlers [<StreamHandler <stderr> (NOTSET)>, <StreamHandler <stdout> (NOTSET)>]
ERROR:root:Test log
Test log
ERROR:root:Test log
Test log
^CTraceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 13, in <module>
    time.sleep(1)
KeyboardInterrupt

$ dotenv run python test.py
^C
Aborted!
```

As a reference / possible solution, we can look at [python-dotenv-run code][1] which uses either `        ctx.exit(subprocess.call([command] + list(args), shell=True))` on windows or `os.execlp(command, command, *args)` otherwise.

p.s: I'll be happy to submit a PR if one of the solutions above is acceptable.

[1]: https://github.com/uranusjr/python-dotenv-run/blob/master/dotenv_run.py#L35-L40
[2]: https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv/blob/master/dotenv/main.py#L286-L301

items.title: Repeated use of set_key messes up dotenv file
items.body:
I'm using python-dotenv 0.9.1 in Jupyter notebooks and Python 3.5. I created an empty dotenv, and used set_key to add keys in one notebook. I ran:

 ```
dotenv_path = os.path.join('.', '.env')  # The location of the dotenv file
if os.path.isfile(dotenv_path):          # Remove any pre-existing dotenv file to ensure a blank slate
    os.remove(dotenv_path)
with open(dotenv_path, 'w'):             # Create an empty dotenv file
    None
# Your docker login and image repository name
dotenv.set_key(dotenv_path, 'docker_login', 'YOUR_DOCKER_LOGIN')
dotenv.set_key(dotenv_path, 'image_repo', '/mlaksdep')
``` 
and got:
 
```
$ cat .env
docker_login="YOUR_DOCKER_LOGIN"
image_repo="/mlaksdep"
 ```
Then in another notebook, I used set_key to add new keys. I ran:
 
```
# The location of the dotenv file
dotenv_path = dotenv.find_dotenv()
 
# If you have multiple subscriptions select the subscription you want to use 
dotenv.set_key(dotenv_path, 'selected_subscription', 'YOUR_SUBSCRIPTION')
 
# Resource group, name and location for AKS cluster
dotenv.set_key(dotenv_path, 'resource_group', 'RESOURCE_GROUP') 
dotenv.set_key(dotenv_path, 'aks_name', 'AKS_CLUSTER_NAME')
dotenv.set_key(dotenv_path, 'location', 'eastus')
``` 

and got:

``` 
$ cat .env
docker_login="YOUR_DOCKER_LOGIN"
image_repo="/mlaksdep"
selected_subscription="YOUR_SUBSCRIPTION"
resource_group="RESOURCE_GROUP"
aks_name="AKS_CLUSTER_NAME"
location="eastus"
```

So far so good. Then, I ran the second cell again to see if this would result in a clean file, but the result was a mess:

```
$ cat .env
docker_login="YOUR_DOCKER_LOGIN"
image_repo="/mlaksdep"
selected_subscription="YOUR_SUBSCRIPTION"resource_group="RESOURCE_GROUP"
aks_name="AKS_CLUSTER_NAME"location="eastus"
resource_group="RESOURCE_GROUP"
location="eastus"
```

When I read in the dotenv and access 'selected_subscription':

```
%dotenv
os.getenv('selected_subscription')
```

I get:

```
'YOUR_SUBSCRIPTION"resource_group="RESOURCE_GROUP'
```

items.title: Variable expansion for 'directory .env is in'
items.body:
https://github.com/altendky/st/blob/de71e071b46bb9863a9bcf94598d7048277f617f/.env#L1
```bash
PYQTDESIGNERPATH=${PYQTDESIGNERPATH};sub/epyqlib/epyqlib;sub/epyqlib/epyqlib/widgets
```

It would be helpful to have a variable that represents the directory that the `.env` file being loaded is located in.  The paths such as `sub/epyqlib/epyqlib` are relative to the `.env`-containing directory but it would be helpful if they could be absolute rather than working-directory dependent.

I imagine something like below though perhaps something that avoids any chance of blocking access to a regular environment variable someone might define.

```bash
PYQTDESIGNERPATH=${PYQTDESIGNERPATH};${ENV_DIR}/sub/epyqlib/epyqlib;${ENV_DIR}/sub/epyqlib/epyqlib/widgets
```

If you like the idea I might be able to come up with a PR.

items.title: Open .env file not set encoding, unable to use unicode string.
items.body: This is the same issue as https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv/issues/74

items.title: Does not load from current directory
items.body:
The README states (emphasis mine)

> The easiest and most common usage consists on calling `load_dotenv` when the application starts, which will load environment variables **from a file named .env in the current directory**

I'm not finding this to be the case. `load_dotenv` defaults to calling `find_dotenv()`:

https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv/blob/b20d818c9296817352f5d0d7cb7b8acd90a2548d/dotenv/main.py#L249-L251

but `usecwd` defaults to `False`:

https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv/blob/b20d818c9296817352f5d0d7cb7b8acd90a2548d/dotenv/main.py#L224-L246

In my case, path becomes '\<venv path>/lib/python3.6/site-packages/dotenv' on line 236 so the current directory is never traversed.

items.title: Allow variables to be prefixed with "export"
items.body:
Hi there. In Rust there's also a [dotenv library](https://crates.io/crates/dotenv#examples) which is very similar but has a nice additional feature:

> You can optionally prefix each line with the word export, which will conveniently allow you to source the whole file on your shell.

So a `.env` file essentially has extended syntax which makes the following valid:

```sh
export MY_API_KEY="blah"
```

This comes in handy because during local development because some command line developer tools need access to the same environment variables that your application does (e.g. if you want to use `curl` to test an API endpoint that your application uses).

items.title: Allow values in .env to overwrite already defined environment variables
items.body:
This should be an optional "overwrite" parameter, False by default.

This would especially be useful when running tests, so test cases can still rely on a .env file and ensure it will override pre-existing environment variables that may not be suitable to use when running tests.

items.title: Profile specific environment variable
items.body:
This library is awesome and I am planning to use it in my application. I am wondering if I could suggest an enhancement which allows depoyment specific configuration variables using this library. 

I am proposing to allow multiple `.env` files such as 
* `.env` : default file that contains configuration that is common across different deployment environments
* `.env.stage`: contains configuration specific to stage deployment. For ex. URL for stage DB
* `.env.production`: contains configuration specific to production deployment. For ex, URL for production DB

This is similar to profile specific configuration that Spring allows. Link  [here](https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/reference/html/boot-features-external-config.html#boot-features-external-config-profile-specific-properties)

What do you guys think about it. I am happy to raise a PR for it.

items.title: Add a `--version` CLI option as per the POSIX standard
items.body:
Almost all the CLI tools in the linux/unix world do follow the [POSIX standard](https://www.gnu.org/prep/standards/html_node/Command_002dLine-Interfaces.html) for the CLI args & options. 
And the options like `--version` to print the version and `--help` to print out usage/help information are two of the most common options almost every CLI tool has. 

I think the `dotenv` tool needs this `--version` option too. 
Something like this:
```bash
$ dotenv --version
dotenv v0.6.4
```
Can do a PR for this if needed. 

Thanks.

items.title: Truncates last character if .env file doesn't contain a trailing newline
items.body:
If I have file.env:
```TEST=eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ```
then the J is truncated from the key TEST
The following file gives the expected result:
```TEST=eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ\n```

items.title: missing cli option to run a given commandline
items.body:
I think it would be neat if the `dotenv` cli tool had an option to run a given commandline WITH the environment vars sourced from specified file, like a RUNNER.

```
# using the env command to print out env
echo "foo=bar" > .env
$ dotenv -f .env env 
foo=bar
```
